column2: Wonderful or supernatural events are not so uncommon, rather they are irregular in their incidence.
column3: Wonderful or supernatural events are not so uncommon, rather they are irregular in their incidence.

column2: Thus there may be not one marvel to speak of in a century, and then often enough comes a plentiful crop of them; monsters of all sorts swarm suddenly upon the earth, comets blaze in the sky, eclipses frighten nature, meteors fall in rain, while mermaids and sirens beguile, and sea-serpents engulf every passing ship, and terrible cataclysms beset humanity.
column3: Thus there may be not one marvel to speak of in a century, and then often enough comes a plentiful crop of them; monsters of all sorts swarm suddenly upon the earth, comets blaze in the sky, eclipses frighten nature, meteors fall in rain, while mermaids and sirens beguile, and sea serpents engulf every passing ship, and terrible cataclysms beset humanity.

column2: But the strange event which I shall here relate came alone, unsupported, without companions into a hostile world, and for that very reason claimed little of the general attention of mankind.
column3: But the strange event which I shall here relate came alone, unsupported, without companions into a hostile world, and for that very reason claimed little of the general attention of mankind.

column2: For the sudden changing of Mrs. Tebrick into a vixen is an established fact which we may attempt to account for as we will.
column3: For the sudden changing of mrs Tebrick into a vixen is an established fact which we may attempt to account for as we will.

column2: Certainly it is in the explanation of the fact, and the reconciling of it with our general notions that we shall find most difficulty, and not in accepting for true a story which is so fully proved, and that not by one witness but by a dozen, all respectable, and with no possibility of collusion between them.
column3: Certainly it is in the explanation of the fact, and the reconciling of it with our general notions that we shall find most difficulty, and not in accepting for true a story which is so fully proved, and that not by one witness but by a dozen, all respectable, and with no possibility of collusion between them.

column2: But here I will confine myself to an exact narrative of the event and all that followed on it.
column3: But here I will confine myself to an exact narrative of the event and all that followed on it.

column2: Yet I would not dissuade any of my readers from attempting an explanation of this seeming miracle because up till now none has been found which is entirely satisfactory.
column3: Yet I would not dissuade any of my readers from attempting an explanation of this seeming miracle because up till now none has been found which is entirely satisfactory.

column2: What adds to the difficulty to my mind is that the metamorphosis occurred when Mrs. Tebrick was a full-grown woman, and that it happened suddenly in so short a space of time.
column3: What adds to the difficulty to my mind is that the metamorphosis occurred when mrs Tebrick was a full grown woman, and that it happened suddenly in so short a space of time.

column2: The sprouting of a tail, the gradual extension of hair all over the body, the slow change of the whole anatomy by a process of growth, though it would have been monstrous, would not have been so difficult to reconcile to our ordinary conceptions, particularly had it happened in a young child.
column3: The sprouting of a tail, the gradual extension of hair all over the body, the slow change of the whole anatomy by a process of growth, though it would have been monstrous, would not have been so difficult to reconcile to our ordinary conceptions, particularly had it happened in a young child.

column2: But here we have something very different.
column3: But here we have something very different.

column2: A grown lady is changed straightway into a fox.
column3: A grown lady is changed straightway into a fox.

column2: There is no explaining that away by any natural philosophy.
column3: There is no explaining that away by any natural philosophy.

column2: The materialism of our age will not help us here.
column3: The materialism of our age will not help us here.

column2: It is indeed a _miracle_; something from outside our world altogether; an event which we would willingly accept if we were to meet it invested with the authority of Divine Revelation in the scriptures, but which we are not prepared to encounter almost in our time, happening in Oxfordshire amongst our neighbours.
column3: It is indeed a underscore miracle underscore; something from outside our world altogether; an event which we would willingly accept if we were to meet it invested with the authority of Divine revelation in the scriptures, but which we are not prepared to encounter almost in our time, happening in Oxfordshire amongst our neighbours.

column2: The only things which go any way towards an explanation of it are but guesswork, and I give them more because I would not conceal anything, than because I think they are of any worth.
column3: The only things which go any way towards an explanation of it are but guesswork, and I give them more because I would not conceal anything, than because I think they are of any worth.

column2: Mrs. Tebrick's maiden name was certainly Fox, and it is possible that such a miracle happening before, the family may have gained their name as a _soubriquet_ on that account.
column3: mrs Tebrick's maiden name was certainly Fox, and it is possible that such a miracle happening before, the family may have gained their name as a underscore soubriquet underscore on that account.

column2: They were an ancient family, and have had their seat at Tangley Hall time out of mind.
column3: They were an ancient family, and have had their seat at Tangley Hall time out of mind.

column2: It is also true that there was a half-tame fox once upon a time chained up at Tangley Hall in the inner yard, and I have heard many speculative wiseacres in the public-houses turn that to great account--though they could not but admit that "there was never one there in Miss Silvia's time." At first I was inclined to think that Silvia Fox, having once hunted when she was a child of ten and having been blooded, might furnish more of an explanation.

column2: She was married in the year 1879 to Mr. Richard Tebrick, after a short courtship, and went to live after their honeymoon at Rylands, near Stokoe, Oxon.
column3: She was married in the year eighteen seventy nine to mr Richard Tebrick, after a short courtship, and went to live after their honeymoon at Rylands, near Stokoe, Oxon.

column2: Tangley Hall is over thirty miles from Stokoe, and is extremely remote.
column3: Tangley Hall is over thirty miles from Stokoe, and is extremely remote.

column2: Indeed to this day there is no proper road to it, which is all the more remarkable as it is the principal, and indeed the only, manor house for several miles round.
column3: Indeed to this day there is no proper road to it, which is all the more remarkable as it is the principal, and indeed the only, manor house for several miles round.

column2: Whether it was from a chance meeting on the roads, or less romantic but more probable, by Mr. Tebrick becoming acquainted with her uncle, a minor canon at Oxford, and thence being invited by him to visit Tangley Hall, it is impossible to say.

column2: But however they became acquainted the marriage was a very happy one.
column3: But however they became acquainted the marriage was a very happy one.

column2: The bride was in her twenty-third year. She was small, with remarkably small hands and feet.
column3: The bride was in her twenty third year. She was small, with remarkably small hands and feet.

column2: It is perhaps worth noting that there was nothing at all foxy or vixenish in her appearance. On the contrary, she was a more than ordinarily beautiful and agreeable woman.
column3: It is perhaps worth noting that there was nothing at all foxy or vixenish in her appearance. On the contrary, she was a more than ordinarily beautiful and agreeable woman.

column2: Her eyes were of a clear hazel but exceptionally brilliant, her hair dark, with a shade of red in it, her skin brownish, with a few dark freckles and little moles.
column3: Her eyes were of a clear hazel but exceptionally brilliant, her hair dark, with a shade of red in it, her skin brownish, with a few dark freckles and little moles.

column2: In manner she was reserved almost to shyness, but perfectly self-possessed, and perfectly well-bred.
column3: In manner she was reserved almost to shyness, but perfectly self possessed, and perfectly well bred.

column2: She had been strictly brought up by a woman of excellent principles and considerable attainments, who died a year or so before the marriage.
column3: She had been strictly brought up by a woman of excellent principles and considerable attainments, who died a year or so before the marriage.

column2: And owing to the circumstance that her mother had been dead many years, and her father bedridden, and not altogether rational for a little while before his death, they had few visitors but her uncle.
column3: And owing to the circumstance that her mother had been dead many years, and her father bedridden, and not altogether rational for a little while before his death, they had few visitors but her uncle.

column2: But perhaps living in so wild a place gave her some disposition to wildness, even in spite of her religious upbringing.

column2: On one of the first days of the year 1880, in the early afternoon, husband and wife went for a walk in the copse on the little hill above Rylands.

column3: Hearing the hunt, mr Tebrick quickened his pace so as to reach the edge of the copse, where they might get a good view of the hounds if they came that way.

column2: Before they gained the edge of the copse she suddenly snatched her hand away from his very violently and cried out, so that he instantly turned his head.
column3: Before they gained the edge of the copse she suddenly snatched her hand away from his very violently and cried out, so that he instantly turned his head.

column2: _Where his wife had been the moment before was a small fox, of a very bright red._ It looked at him very beseechingly, advanced towards him a pace or two, and he saw at once that his wife was looking at him from the animal's eyes.

column2: You may well think if he were aghast: and so maybe was his lady at finding herself in that shape, so they did nothing for nearly half-an-hour but stare at each other, he bewildered, she asking him with her eyes as if indeed she spoke to him: "What am I now become? Have pity on me, husband, have pity on me for I am your wife."

column2: The husband all this while kept turning the thing in his head and gazing on her, but he could make no sense of what had happened, but only comforted himself with the hope that this was but a momentary change, and that presently she would turn back again into the wife that was one flesh with him.

column3: Hearing the shots while he was out in the yard his wife's old nurse, or Nanny, ran up to the bedroom though she had no business there, and so opening the door saw the poor fox dressed in my lady's little jacket lying back in the cushions, and in such a reverie of woe that she heard nothing.

column2: Old Nanny, though she was not expecting to find her mistress there, having been told that she was gone that afternoon to London, knew her instantly, and cried out:
column3: Old Nanny, though she was not expecting to find her mistress there, having been told that she was gone that afternoon to London, knew her instantly, and cried out:

column2: Oh, my poor precious!	Oh, my poor precious!
column3: true

column2: Oh, poor Miss Silvia!
column3: Oh, poor Miss Silvia!

column2: What dreadful change is this?"
column3: What dreadful change is this?"

column2: Then, seeing her mistress start and look at her, she cried out: "But never fear, my darling, it will all come right, your old Nanny knows you, it will all come right in the end."
column3: Then, seeing her mistress start and look at her, she cried out: "But never fear, my darling, it will all come right, your old Nanny knows you, it will all come right in the end."

column2: But though she said this she did not care to look again, and kept her eyes turned away so as not to meet the foxy slit ones of her mistress, for that was too much for her.
column3: But though she said this she did not care to look again, and kept her eyes turned away so as not to meet the foxy slit ones of her mistress, for that was too much for her.

column2: So she hurried out soon, fearing to be found there by Mr. Tebrick, and who knows, perhaps shot, like the dogs, for knowing the secret.
column3: So she hurried out soon, fearing to be found there by mr Tebrick, and who knows, perhaps shot, like the dogs, for knowing the secret.

column2: Mr. Tebrick had all this time gone about paying off his servants and shooting his dogs as if he were in a dream.
column3: mr Tebrick had all this time gone about paying off his servants and shooting his dogs as if he were in a dream.

column2: Now he fortified himself with two or three glasses of strong whisky and went to bed, taking his vixen into his arms, where he slept soundly.
column3: Now he fortified himself with two or three glasses of strong whisky and went to bed, taking his vixen into his arms, where he slept soundly.

column2: Whether she did or not is more than I or anybody else can say.
column3: Whether she did or not is more than I or anybody else can say.
